questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the office for evaluation of right inguinal swelling that he first noticed today while showering. The patient reports mild discomfort. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Current medications include metformin, atorvastatin, and lisinopril. Family history is significant for prostate cancer in the patient’s father. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows enlarged, tender right inguinal and popliteal lymph nodes. Which of the following conditions, if found, would most likely explain this patient’s symptoms?

choices.text: Painless ulceration on the glans penis
Old laceration of the right lateral foot with purulence

questions.solution:
Lymphadenopathy is characterized by an abnormality in size, number, or consistency of any lymphatic nodes and usually occurs in response to infection, malignancy, or an auto-immune condition.

The lower extremity lymphatic system gets divided into both superficial and deep lymphatic vessels, which follow the path of the venous and arterial system. The superficial lymphatic vessels drain lymph from the skin and subcutaneous tissues, whereas the deep lymphatic system drains lymph from both the superficial vessels and deep muscles. The superficial system is further divided into both medial and lateral tracks.
 

Therefore, an infected lesion on the lateral foot would result in the enlargement of both popliteal and inguinal lymph nodes, in contrast to medial foot lesions (only inguinal lymphadenopathy). 

Lymph from the superficial and deep inguinal lymph nodes traverses the external and common iliac nodes before entering the lateral lumbar (aortic) lymph nodes and the lumbar lymphatic trunk.       

Option Analysis

❌ Firm nontender right testicular mass :
Incorrect: Lymph from the testes drains directly into the para-aortic lymph nodes, not the inguinal lymph nodes.  
❌ Asymmetric firm prostatic nodules :
Incorrect: Lymph from the prostate drains into the internal iliac lymph nodes, not the inguinal lymph nodes.  
❌ Painless ulceration on the glans penis :
Incorrect: The glans penis is drained by the deep lymphatic system into the deep (not superficial) inguinal lymph node.  
❌ Exudative pharyngitis  :
Incorrect: Infectious mononucleosis results in cervical (not inguinal) lymph node enlargement. 
✅ Old laceration of the right lateral foot with purulence :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic for evaluation of left lower extremity pain for three weeks. The pain is described as a dull ache located along the left lateral hip and thigh. She does not participate in sports, does not exercise, and has not experienced any recent trauma. Lying on the left hip and prolonged sitting make the pain worse. She reports no significant radiation of the pain. Past medical history is unremarkable, and her only medication is a combined oral contraceptive. Vital signs are within normal limits. Body mass index is 36.2 kg/m2. On physical examination, the patient is well-appearing. There is tenderness to palpation over the left, greater trochanter, and discomfort on passive abduction and adduction of the hip. Sensation and motor strength are intact throughout the lower left extremity. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This 36-year-old woman with obesity presents with three weeks of left lateral thigh pain without an inciting event. She is found to have tenderness over the greater trochanter and pain with adduction and abduction. These findings suggest greater trochanteric pain syndrome, .    

Hip pain is a common reason for patients to seek medical care, both in the clinic and the emergency department. Patients may develop hip pain from hip joint pathology or local musculoskeletal issues causing radiation into the hip joint (e.g., lumbar or knee issues). In many cases, the history and physical examination are sufficient to make a diagnosis. Imaging (e.g., radiographs, ultrasound, computed tomography, magnetic resonance imaging) is sometimes necessary when the diagnosis is unclear.   

Patients with hip pain should have a thorough history evaluating the onset of pain (e.g., abrupt, or gradual, trauma, obvious inciting event), activity level, characteristics of the pain (e.g., type, severity, radiation), and any exacerbating or remitting factors. Rapid weight gain or pregnancy can be triggers for hip pain in cases such as meralgia paresthetica or lumbar radiculopathy. Obesity can predispose to pathologies such as greater trochanteric pain syndrome, as seen in this patient. Physical examination should include joint inspection and palpation, active and passive range of motion, strength testing, special tests, and maneuvers. The FABER (flexion, abduction, external rotation) and FADIR (flexion, adduction, internal rotation) maneuvers can help determine if the pain originates from the hip joint. Many other exam maneuvers (e.g., straight leg raise, pelvic compression test) can help differentiate between the many causes of hip pain.   

Option Analysis

✅ Greater trochanteric pain syndrome:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Meralgia paresthetica:
Incorrect: While meralgia paresthetica can cause lateral thigh pain, it is typically described as burning or numbness in the lateral thigh, which this patient does not exhibit. In addition, it would not explain this patient’s pain in passive hip movements. 
❌ Femoroacetabular impingement:
Incorrect: This condition typically presents with anterior thigh pain that worsens with flexion and internal rotation, rather than lateral hip pain. 
❌ Hip flexor tendonitis:
Incorrect: Hip flexor tendonitis occurs due to overuse of hip flexors (often from cycling or running) and causes anterior thigh pain. This patient does not have the clicking, snapping, and tenderness to palpation over bony prominences which are commonly seen in this condition. 
❌ Labral tear:
Incorrect: Labral tears generally occur abruptly after an inciting mechanism of action that is traumatic. This patient has no clicking, popping, or catching of the hip, nor has she experienced a traumatic incident.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old man presents to the emergency department with left lower extremity pain and swelling. The patient was outside jogging when he suddenly felt a “pop” with associated pain behind the left knee. The left lower extremity has become progressively more swollen and painful over the past few hours. The patient recently traveled to the United States from London. Past medical history is notable for hypertension. Vital signs are within normal limits. Bilateral lower extremity pulses are normal and equal. Physical examination reveals a swollen and tender calf and ecchymosis at the popliteal region. Anterior and posterior drawer tests are negative. An ultrasound of the left calf is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
 

Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient presents with acute onset of pain and swelling of the calf after jogging. Ultrasound reveals a hypoechoic fluid collection. These findings are consistent with a ruptured popliteal (Baker) cyst.

Popliteal cysts are common and reflect an enlargement of the gastrocnemius-semimembranosus bursa that extends into the adjacent knee joint space. Popliteal cysts are commonly associated with osteoarthritis, inflammatory arthritis, and a history of knee trauma (e.g. meniscus tears). They are typically asymptomatic unless rupture occurs.

Clinically, a popliteal cyst often presents as a swollen mass on the posterior aspect of the knee that can cause knee stiffness and difficulty with range of motion during exercise. Occasionally, popliteal cysts can rupture, causing acute pain and swelling of the calf that can mimic deep vein thrombosis. Management of a ruptured popliteal cyst should include ruling out a deep venous thrombosis. The fluid from a ruptured popliteal cyst will gradually be reabsorbed, therefore treatment is typically pain management, rest, and elevation.  

Option Analysis

✅ Ruptured popliteal cyst:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Deep vein thrombosis:
Incorrect: While this patient has recently been on a long-distance flight, his physical examination and ultrasound findings are consistent with a ruptured popliteal cyst. Ultrasound findings associated with a deep vein thrombosis include an incompressible vein and the absence of Doppler flow if the vessel is completely occluded.  
❌ Lymphedema:
Incorrect: Lymphedema often presents as chronic swelling and induration of the lower extremities due to cardiovascular disease, previous radiation, malignancy, infection, or trauma.  
❌ Femoral artery occlusion:
Incorrect: Femoral artery occlusion will often manifest with a pulseless lower extremity with associated acute pain and swelling. Risk factors include atrial fibrillation and thrombophilia.  
❌ Posterior cruciate ligament tear:
Incorrect: Posterior cruciate ligament tears are associated with positive posterior drawer testing. This finding is not present in this patient.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents to the clinic for evaluation of left lower extremity pain. Over the past four weeks, he has developed aching pain in the left anterior hip and thigh. It does not radiate and is not associated with numbness or tingling. He describes it as moderate pain that worsens after prolonged sitting and diminishes upon standing. He does not recall recent trauma to the area. He has a history of playing competitive soccer. Past medical history is noncontributory, and he takes no medication. Vital signs are within normal limits. On physical examination, the patient is well-appearing. There is pain in the left groin with passive flexion and internal rotation at the hip, especially when combined with adduction. Which of the following findings is most likely to be seen on radiographs of the left hip?

choices.text: Joint space narrowing of the hip joint
Subchondral bone destruction of the hip joint

questions.solution:
This 30-year-old man with a history of playing competitive soccer presents with a gradual onset of left anterior hip pain over four weeks that worsens with prolonged sitting and improves with standing. Physical exam is significant for pain in the left groin with flexion, adduction, and internal rotation of the hip (FADIR maneuver). These findings in this athletic patient without an inciting event likely represent femoroacetabular impingement. Left hip radiographs would most likely show Cam morphology.    

Hip pain is quite a common reason for patients to seek medical care. It can be caused by hip joint pathology or from local musculoskeletal issues causing radiation into the hip joint (e.g., lumbar or knee issues). In many cases, the history and physical examination are sufficient to make a diagnosis. However, imaging may be required.    

When the diagnosis is uncertain, radiographs of the hip and pelvis should be obtained. Further imaging such as ultrasound, computed tomography (CT), or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) may also be required if radiographs are unrevealing, there is concern for significant soft tissue pathology (e.g., ligament, muscle, tendon) or infection, or for surgical planning.    

Fractures or dislocations are usually visible on plain radiographs, and a defect of the labrum can be seen on X-rays. Radiographic signs of hip osteoarthritis include subchondral sclerosis, osteophytes, and joint space narrowing.    

Femoroacetabular impingement is when there is abutment of the femoral head-neck junction against the acetabular rim due to an aspherical femoral head (Cam morphology), over-coverage of the femoral head (pincer morphology) or a combination of the two morphologies. This can result in bony prominence of the femoral head and flattening of the head-neck junction as seen in the radiograph below.  



Image courtesy of STATdx   
Figure 1. Cam morphology of femoroacetabular impingement: The white arrow shows the bony prominence of the femoral head, resulting in flattening of the head-neck junction.   

Option Analysis

✅ Cam morphology of femoroacetabular impingement:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Joint space narrowing of the hip joint :
Incorrect: While joint space narrowing is typically seen in osteoarthritis. Osteoarthritis would be an unlikely cause of hip pain in this young, otherwise healthy patient. Femoroacetabular impingement is the most likely diagnosis with Cam morphology present on radiographs. 
❌ Osteophytes at the hip joint:
Incorrect: Osteophytes are typically seen in osteoarthritis. This patient is an otherwise healthy 30-year-old, making this diagnosis unlikely. Femoroacetabular impingement is the most likely diagnosis with Cam morphology present on radiographs. 
❌ Defect of the hip labrum:
Incorrect: A hip labral defect would suggest a labral tear, which typically occurs acutely due to a traumatic inciting event (e.g. sports injury), which does not fit with this patient’s presentation. Femoroacetabular impingement is the most likely diagnosis with Cam morphology present on radiographs. 
❌ Subchondral bone destruction of the hip joint:
Incorrect: Subchondral bone destruction may be seen in severe cases of septic arthritis. This patient’s pain level, chronic or subacute course, and lack of fever do not support a diagnosis of septic arthritis. Femoroacetabular impingement is the most likely diagnosis with Cam morphology present on radiographs.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman presents to the primary care physician for evaluation of right shoulder, neck, and arm pain for the past several weeks. The patient reports associated weakness in her right arm, particularly with overhead movements. The patient describes the pain as “burning” and says it shoots down her right arm. She does not recall any history of injury or trauma. The patient has a history of obesity and hypertension for which she takes amlodipine. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination of the right shoulder shows no evidence of ecchymosis, swelling, erythema, or deformity. The patient has diminished range of motion at the shoulder secondary to pain. Sensation is mildly diminished over the lateral shoulder with noted weakness with shoulder abduction. The patient experiences the pain when the examiner extends and rotates the neck to the right and presses downward on the head. Which of the following is the best next step for diagnosing the underlying cause of shoulder pain in this patient?

choices.text: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the cervical spine
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the right shoulder

questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of atraumatic right shoulder pain and neck and right arm pain. This patient's description of the pain is consistent with neuropathic pain, which can present as shooting and burning pain that follows a nerve distribution. Moreover, this patient has associated neurovascular deficits, further supporting a diagnosis of cervical radiculopathy. Therefore, the best next step is to obtain an MRI of the cervical spine to determine if there is cervical radiculopathy.        

Shoulder pain is a common symptom with many potential underlying causes, including conditions affecting the joint, capsule, tendons, or bursa. When performing a history and physical examination for a patient with shoulder pain, the first step is to identify if the patient’s shoulder pain is due to trauma or infection.     

When no history of trauma is present, patients should subsequently be assessed for findings that may suggest infection (e.g. fevers, chills, immunosuppression, warmth, or swelling over the joint). If signs of infection are present, patients should be assessed for septic arthritis or osteomyelitis with blood work, synovial fluid analysis, and MRI.    

When no findings of infection are present, further history can aid in narrowing the diagnosis. Patients with neuropathic shoulder pain often describe pain as burning, lancinating, shooting, or electric in nature and running down the arm. Patients may have findings of neuromuscular/sensory deficits on physical examination, such as decreased sensation and weakness, as seen in this patient. This patient also has a positive Spurling test, indicating cervical radiculopathy. Patients with cervical radiculopathy typically have cervical spinous disease, such as nerve root impingement, as the underlying cause of shoulder pain. In contrast, patients with nociceptive pain will often describe pain that is localized, dull, or sharp. Patients with pain that is nociceptive should undergo further assessment on physical exam for the primary tissue that is damaged (joints, capsules, soft tissues).    

Option Analysis

✅ Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the cervical spine:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Synovial fluid analysis:
Incorrect: Synovial fluid analysis is indicated for patients when there is suspicion for septic arthritis. Signs, symptoms, and findings indicating septic arthritis include fevers, chills, and swelling/erythema over the shoulder. This patient's history and physical examination are more consistent with cervical radiculopathy.  
❌ X-ray of the right shoulder:
Incorrect: Given this patient has no history of trauma, an X-ray of the right shoulder is unlikely to provide additional diagnostic utility. An MRI of the cervical spine is more likely to reveal the underlying diagnosis.  
❌ Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR)/c-reactive protein (CRP):
Incorrect: Inflammatory marker analysis is indicated for patients when there is suspicion of septic arthritis, which typically presents with fevers, chills, and swelling/erythema over the shoulder. This patient's history and physical exam findings are more consistent with cervical radiculopathy. 
❌ Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the right shoulder:
Incorrect: This patient has clinical findings suggesting neuropathic pain from cervical radiculopathy. Therefore, primary shoulder pathology that would be seen with MRI is unlikely the cause of the pain.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old man presents to the emergency department following a motor vehicle collision. He is experiencing severe pain in his face and neck. He has significant neck swelling with odynophagia localized to the left side. The odynophagia is worsened with opening his mouth, speaking, or swallowing. The patient has no dyspnea or signs of airway compromise. Head CT and sagittal neck X-ray are shown. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism of injury?  


Image credit: Pubmed

choices.text: Blunt force trauma to the neck
Chronic avascular necrosis of the axis

questions.solution:
This patient presents to the emergency department with a hyoid fracture. For these fractures, it is critically important to closely understand the true mechanism of injury. Approximately 50% of hyoid fractures occur due to strangulation, with an additional 37% due to hangings. Due to the anatomical location and close interrelationship of the hyoid bone with the trachea, esophagus, and carotids, early complications of hyoid fractures include subcutaneous emphysema, crepitus dyspnea, pharyngeal tears, and thyroid cartilage injury. Late complications include dyspnea, stridor, and pseudoaneurysm of the external carotid. For this reason, close observation for 72 hours is strongly recommended. Surgical intervention is not required for most of these complications unless respiratory compromise becomes imminent, in which case laryngoscopic evaluation is common.  

Option Analysis

❌ Blunt force trauma to the neck  :
Incorrect: Although this patient reports being in a motor vehicle collision, the hyoid fracture shown in the above radiograph is most likely from either strangulation (50% of cases) or hanging (37% of cases).  
✅ Strangulation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Carotid artery laceration:
Incorrect: Imaging here shows a fracture of the hyoid bone. Lacerations of the carotid at this level are less likely.  
❌ Chronic avascular necrosis of the axis  :
Incorrect: Imaging here shows a fracture of the hyoid bone. A fracture of the axis (or C2 vertebrae) would be seen much higher (at the level of the occiput) on imaging.  
❌ Malignant fracture:
Incorrect: Discovering novel osteosarcoma or soft tissue tumor affecting the hyoid bone is extremely rare. Moreover, most fractures related to the hyoid are due to strangulation.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 3, comes to the office for the evaluation of an abnormal protrusion in her abdomen. She is 6 weeks postpartum and reports that there has been a protrusion since she delivered the baby. The pregnancy was uncomplicated and ended with a normal vaginal delivery of a 7-lb. infant. Past medical history is unremarkable. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals a slight bulge in the epigastric region. The patient is asked to raise her head while being in the supine position with knees flexed. A diffuse fusiform bulge becomes prominent extending from the xiphoid to the umbilicus. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This postpartum patient presents with a midline abdominal bulge that becomes prominent on the contraction of the rectus abdominis muscle. She most likely has rectus abdominis diastasis, which refers to an abnormal separation between the two medial sides of the rectus muscles, with a laxity at the linea alba. A distance of two centimeters is usually considered abnormal in the midline abdomen above the umbilicus.



Risk factors include elevated intra-abdominal pressure, including obesity and pregnancy; conditions that weaken the abdominal wall (e.g. connective tissue disorders); and prior abdominal surgery. It most commonly affects infants (due to the partially developed rectus abdominis) and pregnant people (especially multiparous, due to repetitive stretching of the abdominal muscles). Of note, rectus abdominis diastasis is not a true hernia, as the midline fascial layer of the abdominal wall is intact; therefore, incarceration and strangulation do not occur.

Affected patients usually present with a midline abdominal ridge that becomes more prominent with straining and may disappear when the abdominal muscles are relaxed. Diagnosis is based on physical examination, and abdominal ultrasound can be performed to rule out hernia.

Option Analysis

❌ Epigastric hernia:
Incorrect: Although an epigastric hernia can present as a bulge between the umbilicus and xiphoid process, it is not usually fusiform, as it is a result of a defect in the linea alba of the abdominal wall. Moreover, it is less commonly associated with pregnancy than diastasis recti.
✅ Rectus divarication:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Rectus sheath hematoma:
Incorrect: A rectus sheath hematoma results from the disruption of one of the branches of the inferior epigastric artery. This condition presents with acute abdominal pain and a palpable abdominal wall mass that does not change during contraction of the rectus muscle.
❌ Incisional hernia:
Incorrect: An incisional hernia can develop at the site of a previous abdominal incision. Important risk factors include diabetes, immunosuppression, obesity, smoking, malnutrition, and connective tissue disorders. This patient has no surgical history.
❌ Lipoma:
Incorrect: A lipoma is a lump under the skin that results from the overgrowth of fat cells. Physical examination usually shows a mobile, painless mass with a soft consistency. This patient, with a new bulge postpartum, is more likely to have diastasis recti.

questions.text: A 40-year-old comes to the office for the evaluation of an abdominal lump. The patient also reports intermittent pain in the upper abdomen that gets worse when they lift heavy weights at the gym. The rest of the review of systems is unremarkable. Past medical history is noncontributory. BMI is 35 kg/m2. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a 2 cm midline bulge between the umbilicus and xiphoid process. The bulge is erythematous, tender to palpation, and increases in size when the patient is asked to cough. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient’s midline abdominal bulge in the epigastric region that increases in size with increased intraabdominal pressure is most likely an epigastric hernia, which results when there is a defect in the linea alba of the abdominal wall.

A hernia is when an organ protrudes through the body wall that normally contains it. Ventral abdominal hernias occur in the anterior abdominal wall and can be divided into:

  •  Epigastric hernia (as described above) 
  •  Umbilical (periumbilical) hernia: Occurs near the umbilicus, often associated with pregnancy 
  •  Spigelian hernia: Located in the "Spigelian hernia belt," a transverse 6-centimeter-wide zone around the level of the arcuate line 
  • Incisional hernia: Usually develops on a prior surgical incision site where the fascia never fully healed
Risk factors for ventral hernias include obesity, pregnancy, heavy lifting, genetic defects, aging, and intractable vomiting.



Reducible hernias can be pushed back into the abdomen by applying manual pressure, whereas irreducible (i.e. incarcerated) hernias are trapped within the hernia sac and cannot be reduced. An incarcerated hernia can progress to become a strangulated hernia due to the progressive edema secondary to impaired blood and lymphatic flow, leading to ischemic necrosis of the herniated contents.



Option Analysis

✅ Defect in the linea alba:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Defect in the Spigelian aponeurosis:
Incorrect: A defect in the Spigelian aponeurosis can result in Spigelian hernia, which is located in the "Spigelian hernia belt," a transverse 6-centimeter-wide zone around the level of the arcuate line, which is the caudal-most extent of the posterior rectus sheath. It is not located in the epigastric region.
❌ Patent processus vaginalis:
Incorrect: Patent processus vaginalis can result in indirect inguinal hernia, in which the abdominal contents go through the inguinal ring and protrudes lateral to the epigastric vessels into the inguinal canal and sometimes the scrotum. This patient has an epigastric hernia.
❌ Weakness of the obturator membrane:
Incorrect: Weakness of the obturator membrane can cause an obturator hernia, in which the abdominal contents protrude through the obturator foramen, which is located on the anterolateral aspect of the pelvic wall. This patient has an epigastric hernia.
❌ Weakness of the transversalis fascia:
Incorrect: Weakness of the transversalis fascia can result in direct inguinal hernia, in which the abdominal contents protrude medially to the inferior epigastric vessels within the Hesselbach triangle and appear in the groin (unlike the epigastric bulge in this patient).

questions.text:
A 36-year-old woman who has no significant past medical history presents to the emergency department for evaluation following a motor vehicle collision. According to emergency medical services, the patient was the unrestrained driver of a vehicle traveling approximately 45 miles per hour that hit into the back of a stationary truck. Upon arrival, the patient is boarded, collared, and states she has pain in the back of the neck. The patient states, “My neck is killing me. I slammed my chin on the steering wheel”. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 104/min, respirations are 21/min, blood pressure is 172/94 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. A cervical spine radiograph is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?  


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

choices.text: Avulsion fracture of C3 spinous process
Vertebral body compression fracture of C2

questions.solution:
This patient presents after a motor vehicle collision wherein she likely sustained a hyperextension injury to the neck. The radiograph demonstrates spondylolisthesis of the C2 vertebra, which can be an unstable cervical spine injury. However this type of fracture typically does not cause spinal cord injury.  

Traumatic spondylolisthesis and associated fractures of the C2 vertebra are also known as “hangman’s injuries” or “hangman’s fracture”—since this was a common finding in post-mortem autopsies of criminals executed by hanging. This injury pattern now most commonly occurs from car crashes and falls. It is caused by forcible hyperextension of the head, usually with the distraction of the neck, or without distraction of the neck but with axial loading.  

The fracture typically occurs in the axis's superior and inferior articular processes, with an associated displacement of the C2 vertebra anteriorly on C3. Spinal cord or brainstem injury can occur if the fracture is unstable. Radiographically, it can be identified by anterior displacement of the C2 vertebra relative to C3 If the fracture is stable then treatment is typically conservative with external fixation or bracing.  

Option Analysis

✅ Spondylolisthesis of C2  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Burst fracture of C1  :
Incorrect: A burst fracture of C1 is also known as a Jefferson fracture. It can be an unstable cervical spine injury, but typically is not and is treated with a collar. This injury more commonly occurs after a direct compression force is applied to the top of the head, and it may be difficult to identify on radiographs.  
❌ Odontoid fracture:
Incorrect: The odontoid process, or dens, is a superior projecting bony element from the second cervical vertebrae that may become fractured during hyperextension or hyperflexion injuries. An associated fracture of the dens is not apparent on this radiograph. It is best identified on CT imaging of the head and neck.  
❌ Avulsion fracture of C3 spinous process:
Incorrect: An avulsion fracture of a spinous process, also referred to as a “clay-shoveler fracture”, is a rare fracture which is considered a stable cervical spine injury. There is no evidence of a C3 spinous process fracture in this patient’s radiograph.  
❌ Vertebral body compression fracture of C2:
Incorrect: Vertebral body compression fractures most commonly arise in patients with  underlying osteoporosis. They appear as a wedge-shaped vertebral body on radiographic imaging.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old man is brought to the emergency department to be evaluated for head trauma following a dive into a shallow swimming pool. Upon extrication, the patient was found to have profuse bleeding from the scalp. Reflexes in the upper and lower extremities were intact, there was good sphincter tone and no Babinski sign. He was subsequently brought to the nearest emergency department in a cervical collar and sent to the CT scanner for further evaluation. A CT of the cervical spine is shown below, as is the lateral cervical radiograph. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of injury resulting in these imaging findings?



Images reproduced from Radiopedia

choices.text: Vertical compression to the neck from axial loading
Hyperflexion and internal rotation of the neck
Lateral force applied to the neck

questions.solution:
This patient presents with imaging findings of anterior and posterior arch fractures or a burst fracture of the C1 vertebra (atlas), also known as a Jefferson fracture. The most common mechanism of injury associated with this fracture pattern is a vertical compression force applied to the neck from axial loading.  

Jefferson fractures often result from motor vehicle accidents, shallow-water diving injuries, or falls from extreme heights. This fracture pattern involves a fracture of the anterior and posterior arches of C1, most commonly due to axial loading transmitted through the occipital condyles to the lateral masses. Jefferson fractures are not typically associated with spinal cord injuries unless a bone fragment injures the spinal cord. However they are often associated with other cervical spine injuries. They are considered stable and treated conservatively with cervical spine collar immobilization unless the transverse atlantal ligament is disrupted which is an unstable injury.  

Imaging of the vertebral arteries with CT angiography or MR angiography is an important part of the evaluation due to concerns for the rare complication of late-onset neurologic deficits from cerebellar infarction caused by blood flow disruptions to the vertebral arteries. When an injury occurs to the vertebral arteries, patients are at risk for developing stroke syndromes such as lateral medullary syndrome, Horner syndrome, ataxia, or the inability to sense pain or temperature.

Option Analysis

✅ Vertical compression to the neck from axial loading  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hyperextension of the neck:
Incorrect: A hangman fracture refers to a fracture of both pedicles, or pars interarticularis, of the C2 vertebra which can lead to traumatic spondylolisthesis of C2. The most common mechanism of injury associated with this traumatic injury is hyperextension of the neck. The lateral cervical radiograph does not show fractures of the C2 pedicles. In contrast, this patient has a fracture of the C1 vertebra on CT.  
❌ Hyperflexion of the neck  :
Incorrect: Hyperflexion of the neck is the most common mechanism of injury associated with a fracture of the spinous processes of the lower cervical or upper thoracic vertebrae. This injury is also known as a “clay-shoveler fracture”. The lateral cervical radiograph does not show fracture of the spinous processes.  
❌ Hyperflexion and internal rotation of the neck:
Incorrect: Hyperflexion and internal rotation of the neck is the most common mechanism associated with an atlanto-axial dislocation. There is no evidence of the on lateral cervical radiograph of atlanto-axial dislocation, and the patient has none of the neurologic symptoms that are typically seen with atlanto-axial dislocation.  
❌ Lateral force applied to the neck  :
Incorrect: A lateral force applied to the neck is more likely to injure the vertebral transverse processes. The CT does not demonstrate transverse process fractures.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old man presents to the emergency department after a fall down the last step of a flight of stairs. The patient drank several beers earlier during the day and slipped as he was going down the staircase. He landed face first and hyperextended his neck. The patient has facial pain and pain in the posterior cervical spine. Past medical history is unremarkable. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 162/84 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. The patient is placed in a cervical spine collar. A CT of the cervical spine is obtained, and the coronal and sagittal views are shown below. Which of the following best describes this pattern of injury?  



Image reproduced from Radiopedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents following a fall down the last step of a flight of stairs and associated neck hypertension. CT imaging demonstrates a fracture through the base of the odontoid process, which is consistent with a type II odontoid fracture.  

Odontoid fractures are the most common type of cervical spine injury seen in older patients and refer to fractures of the odontoid process (dens of C2 vertebra). They often occur in older patients as a result of low-energy falls. This injury pattern most commonly occurs secondary to forced hyperextension of the neck. Less commonly, it can arise via forced hyperflexion of the neck. These fractures can be recognized by bone discontinuation in the dens on an open mouth radiograph or CT scan.  

Odontoid fractures are classified into three distinct injury patterns. A type I odontoid fracture refers to an avulsion fracture of the tip of the odontoid process and represents a stable cervical spine injury. Type II and type III odontoid fractures represent unstable cervical spine injuries and refer to a fracture through the base of the odontoid process and a fracture through the C2 vertebral body, respectively. In particular, type II injuries are at risk of avascular necrosis and nonunion due to poor blood supply. Type III injuries may heal faster due to adequate blood supply to the cervical body but are at higher risk of causing neurologic injury secondary to mechanical instability.

Option Analysis

✅ Type II odontoid injury:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Type I odontoid fracture:
Incorrect: A type I odontoid fracture occurs when only the rostral tip of the odontoid process is avulsed. It is most often a stable cervical spine injury. This CT shows that there is a fracture through the base of the odontoid process not the tip..  
❌ Burst fracture of C1:
Incorrect: A burst fracture of C1 is also known as a Jefferson fracture. Jefferson fractures typically occur after a direct compression force from axial loading to the top of the head, not from a hyperextension injury of the neck as seen in this patient.  
❌ Type III odontoid injury  :
Incorrect: A type III odontoid fracture is a fracture through the body of the C2 vertebra. In contrast, this patient’s CT demonstrates a fracture through the base of the odontoid process.  
❌ Spondylolisthesis of C2:
Incorrect: Traumatic spondylolisthesis and associated fracture of the C2 vertebra are known as “hangman’s injuries” or “hangman’s fracture”. This type of injury typically results from forced hyperextension of the neck. Spondylolisthesis can be identified by anterior displacement of the C2 vertebra relative to the surrounding cervical vertebrae which is not seen in the sagittal view of this CT.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman comes to the emergency room for evaluation of palpitations. An electrocardiogram is performed and demonstrates sinus tachycardia. A carotid sinus massage is completed, and the patient’s heart rate decreases from 180/min to 100/min. Which of the following is true regarding the response seen in this patient?

choices.text: Afferent signals from the carotid body are transmitted via the glossopharyngeal nerve, while efferent impulses (the response) are transmitted via the vagus nerve.
Afferent signals from the carotid body and efferent signals to the aortic arch baroreceptors are transmitted via the vagus nerve.
Afferent signals from the carotid body are transmitted via the vagus nerve, while the efferent impulses (the response) are transmitted via the glossopharyngeal nerve.
Afferent signals from the carotid body and efferent signals (the response) are transmitted via the glossopharyngeal nerve.
Afferent signals from the carotid body are transmitted via the glossopharyngeal nerve, while the efferent impulses (the response) are transmitted via the accessory nerve.

questions.solution:
Baroreceptors are sensory receptors that detect changes in blood pressure and can modulate autonomic control of the heart and blood vessels through sympathetic and parasympathetic output. Baroreceptors are located within the carotid sinus and aortic arch. The glossopharyngeal nerve carries afferent impulses from the carotid sinus, whereas the vagus nerve carries afferent signals from the aortic arch. Signals from these receptors are relayed to the nucleus tractus solitarius (NTS) in the medulla. Autonomic output from the NTS is distributed via parasympathetic fibers of the vagus nerve or the sympathetic nervous system, depending on whether the body is trying to increase or decrease blood pressure.  



Baroreceptors in the carotid sinus and aortic arch are activated and send afferent impulses to the NTS. Efferent sympathetic fibers then relay signals from the NTS to the rest of the body, causing alterations in vasoconstriction, heart rate, and cardiac contractility. For instance, in cases of hypotension, there is diminished arterial stretch, which is noted by the baroreceptors, prompting a sympathetic response.  

In contrast, hypertension causes increased stretching of the arterial walls and baroreceptors. Signals are then forwarded to the NTS. Efferent parasympathetic output is relayed by the vagus nerve to the heart, resulting in bradycardia.  

Carotid sinus massage is a maneuver that can diagnose and treat supraventricular tachycardias such as atrioventricular reentrant tachycardia (AVRT) and AV nodal reentrant tachycardia (AVNRT). Pressure on the carotid sinus stretches the carotid sinus and baroreceptor activation. These changes increase parasympathetic output via the vagus nerve, slowing sinus node impulse formation and lengthening the AV node refractory period. These changes can potentially terminate an abnormal rhythm.  



Option Analysis

✅ Afferent signals from the carotid body are transmitted via the glossopharyngeal nerve, while efferent impulses (the response) are transmitted via the vagus nerve.:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Afferent signals from the carotid body and efferent signals to the aortic arch baroreceptors are transmitted via the vagus nerve.:
Incorrect: This patient demonstrated the baroreceptor reflex, in which the glossopharyngeal nerve transmits afferent information from the carotid body to the nucleus tractus solitarius. The vagus nerve then transmits efferent signals from the nucleus tractus solitarius to the aortic arch baroreceptors.  
❌ Afferent signals from the carotid body are transmitted via the vagus nerve, while the efferent impulses (the response) are transmitted via the glossopharyngeal nerve.:
Incorrect: This patient demonstrated the baroreceptor reflex, in which afferent signals from the carotid body are transmitted via the glossopharyngeal nerve, and subsequent efferent signals (the response) to the aortic arch baroreceptors are transmitted via the vagus nerve.  
❌ Afferent signals from the carotid body and efferent signals (the response) are transmitted via the glossopharyngeal nerve. :
Incorrect: In the baroreceptor reflex, efferent signals from the nucleus tractus solitarius are transmitted to the heart via the vagus nerve, not the glossopharyngeal nerve.  
❌ Afferent signals from the carotid body are transmitted via the glossopharyngeal nerve, while the efferent impulses (the response) are transmitted via the accessory nerve.    :
Incorrect: The accessory nerve (cranial nerve XI) is a pure motor nerve with no parasympathetic input. In contrast, the vagus nerve mediates the efferent response in the baroreceptor reflex.

questions.text: A medication for the treatment of chronic pain is under study in rat models. In addition to analgesia, administration of this medication results in decreased gastrointestinal motility, bowel movements, and respiratory depression. Stimulation of which of the following receptors is most likely responsible for these additional clinical effects?
questions.solution:
There are three primary receptors involved in opiate pharmacology: μ, δ, and κ. Most opiates operate primarily on the μ-opioid receptor, which in addition to analgesia, contributes to the side effects of constipation, decreased gastrointestinal motility, and respiratory depression.     

While there is some overlap and distinction of effects at these receptors, they are all G-protein coupled receptors. The binding of associated endogenous ligands modulates synaptic transmission via closure of presynaptic Ca2+ channels and opening of postsynaptic K+ channels. These changes inhibit the release of ACh, norepinephrine, 5-HT, glutamate, and substance P, resulting in decreased synaptic signal transmission.  



Option Analysis

✅ μ-opioid receptor :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ κ-opioid receptor :
Incorrect: The κ-opioid receptor contributes to analgesia at the spinal level and may elicit sedation, dysphoria, and hallucinations. Agonism at this receptor does not induce constipation.   
❌ δ-opioid receptor :
Incorrect: The δ-opioid receptor is primarily responsible for analgesia and has proconvulsant properties. Agonism at this receptor does not induce constipation.   
❌ GABAA receptor :
Incorrect: Medications including benzodiazepines, barbiturates, and sedative-hypnotics act on the GABAA receptor. They do not typically cause constipation as a side effect.   
❌ NMDA receptor :
Incorrect: Ketamine is a dissociate agent that acts on the NMDA receptor. It does not typically cause constipation as a side effect.

questions.text: An experiment investigates the analgesic effects of three opioids in patients with refractory pain. The drugs are A, B, and C. A graph demonstrating the study results is shown below. Drug B is most similar to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Efficacy is the maximal effect a particular medication achieves when taken at the highest tolerated dose. The plateau value represents efficacy on a dose-response curve.  

A dose-response curve shows the relationship between the concentration of medication in the body (x-axis) and the effect it produces.    

As the medication concentration increases, more receptor-drug complexes form. Eventually, all the receptors get occupied, so the curve flattens out, and the maximum response or effect (Emax) is achieved. This process is described as a graded dose-response relationship.  

Based on the maximal pharmacologic response that occurs when all receptors are occupied, agonists can be divided into partial agonists and full agonists. Partial agonists (e.g. buprenorphine) produce a lower response at full receptor occupancy than full agonists (e.g., morphine, heroin, codeine).  



Option Analysis

❌ Morphine:
Incorrect: Morphine is a full opioid receptor agonist and will have high efficacy. As a result, its effect will be most similar to that of Drug A.
✅ Buprenorphine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Naloxone:
Incorrect: Naloxone is a full opioid receptor antagonist. It is usually used to treat acute opioid intoxication. The effects of naloxone will be most similar to those of Drug C.
❌ Codeine :
Incorrect: Codeine is a full opioid receptor agonist. Its effect will be similar to that of Drug A.
❌ Naltrexone:
Incorrect: Naltrexone is a full opioid receptor antagonist and is usually used to prevent relapse in patients with a history of opioid addiction. The effects of naltrexone will be most similar to those of Drug C.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) began his first cycle of chemotherapy two days ago. Today, he endorses severe nausea and vomiting. Which of the following structures is involved in the pathway responsible for this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient's nausea and vomiting are a result of stimulation of the chemoreceptor trigger zone (CTZ) located within the area postrema. This structure is found on the floor of the fourth ventricle at the caudal end of the rhomboid fossa, near the entrance of the central canal. The CTZ does not have a well-developed blood-brain barrier but rather fenestrated capillaries, allowing chemical substances to cross from the bloodstream. Thus the CTZ  can sense emetogenic substances, including chemotherapeutics, alcohol, toxins, and hormones that directly stimulate the vomiting reflex.  

Option Analysis

✅ Area postrema  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Medial geniculate nucleus  :
Incorrect: The medial geniculate nucleus is a thalamic structure that projects to the auditory cortex of the temporal lobe and is involved in processing auditory information.  
❌ Lateral geniculate nucleus  :
Incorrect: The lateral geniculate nucleus is a thalamic structure that projects to the calcarine sulcus and is involved in processing visual information.  
❌ Posterior hypothalamus  :
Incorrect: The posterior hypothalamus is responsible for the body's ability to warm itself via sympathetic output.  
❌ Ventral pons  :
Incorrect: The ventral pons contains the corticospinal tract (limb/torso movements), corticobulbar tract (face/head/neck movements), and abducens nucleus (lateral eye movements).

questions.text: A 66-year-old man is evaluated for dysphagia and recurrent aspiration pneumonia. The patient has hypertension and often forgets to take his blood pressure medications. Temperature is 37.0ºC (98.6ºF), blood pressure is 162/95 mmHg, and pulse is 87/min. Physical examination reveals an absent right-sided gag reflex. Loss of function of the nerve responsible for transmitting the afferent signal of this reflex is associated with which of the following additional neurological deficits?

choices.text: Loss of sensation in the posterior one-third of the tongue.
Loss of taste sensation in the anterior two-thirds of the tongue

questions.solution:
This patient with a history of poorly controlled hypertension and recurrent aspiration pneumonia presents with an absent right-sided gag reflex. Afferent signals of the gag reflex are sent via the glossopharyngeal nerve, which is also responsible for sensation in the posterior one-third of the tongue.  

A reflex arc typically consists of sensory receptors, the afferent sensory nerve that sends an impulse to the central nervous system, and an efferent motor nerve that transmits a motor response. The gag reflex is mediated by the glossopharyngeal nerve and the vagus nerve. The gag reflex is triggered via contact with the posterior pharynx, tonsillar area, or tongue base. Afferent nerve impulses (sensory limb) are sent through the glossopharyngeal nerve (IX), which also aids in swallowing by supplying the stylopharyngeus muscle and carries taste from the posterior third of the tongue. Efferent nerve impulses (motor limb) are then sent through the pharyngeal branches of the vagus nerve (X), which also innervates muscles of the pharynx and larynx and helps regulate blood pressure.  



The gag reflex is assessed when there is reason to suspect reduced palatal strength or sensation (e.g. clinical symptoms of stroke). It is evaluated by observing the patient’s response when the posterior pharynx is touched with a cotton swab. The reflex elicited on one side can be compared with that of the contralateral side to assess for asymmetry.  

A normal gag reflex involves brisk, symmetrical elevation of the soft palate and contraction of pharyngeal muscles. If both cranial nerves IX and X are damaged, stimulation of the affected side would fail to elicit a reflex. Loss of the gag reflex makes patients susceptible to aspiration and pneumonia.  

Option Analysis

✅ Loss of sensation in the posterior one-third of the tongue.:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Loss of taste sensation in the anterior two-thirds of the tongue:
Incorrect: Taste sensation from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue is transmitted via the facial nerve, while somatosensation is transmitted via the trigeminal nerve. In contrast, the glossopharyngeal nerve, which carries the afferent signals of the gag reflex and is likely damaged here, is responsible for taste and somatosensation of the posterior one-third of the tongue.     
❌ Vocal cord paralysis:
Incorrect: The vagus nerve is responsible for the motor supply of the vocal cords. It carries the efferent signal of the gag reflex. The glossopharyngeal nerve carries the afferent signal of the gag reflex, in addition to sensation in the posterior one-third of the tongue.
❌ Tongue paralysis:
Incorrect: Most of the tongue muscles are supplied by the hypoglossal nerve. The exception is the palatoglossal muscle provided by the vagus nerve. However, this patient has an absent gag reflex, and the afferent signals of the gag reflex are transmitted via the glossopharyngeal nerve, which is also responsible for sensation in the posterior one-third of the tongue.
❌ Loss of the cough reflex:
Incorrect: The vagus nerve mediates both the afferent and efferent signals of the cough reflex. In contrast, this patient has an absent gag reflex. The afferent signals of the gag reflex are transmitted via the glossopharyngeal nerve, which is also responsible for sensation in the posterior one-third of the tongue.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of dysarthria and dysphagia. The patient’s symptoms started three months ago. Past medical history includes type II diabetes mellitus and hypertension, both poorly controlled. Current medications include metformin, glyburide, losartan, and atorvastatin. He has a 40-pack-year smoking history. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), blood pressure is 162/89 mmHg, and pulse is 80/min. Examination of the head and neck reveals atrophy and fasciculations of the tongue. Rightward deviation of the tongue is noted when the patient is asked to protrude the tongue. He has no sensory or motor abnormalities in other parts of the face or the body. Further evaluation of this patient’s clinical history will most likely reveal the following?

choices.text: History of stroke involving the right medullary branch of the vertebral artery
Lymph node biopsy from the posterior cervical lymph nodes
Thyroidectomy with superior and inferior thyroid arteries dissection
Mitral stenosis associated with left atrial dilation

questions.solution:
The hypoglossal nerve emerges from the anterior surface of the medulla oblongata and leaves the skull through the hypoglossal canal. It descends through the neck close to the internal carotid artery, internal jugular vein, and vagus nerve. The hypoglossal nerve supplies the intrinsic and extrinsic muscles of the tongue, except the palatoglossal muscle, which is supplied by the vagus nerve.    

Hypoglossal nerve injury can occur anywhere along the nerve’s course. Etiologies include tumor, cerebrovascular injury, demyelinating diseases, injury following cervical spine surgery, and traumatic injury. In addition, the hypoglossal nerve can be injured during operations involving the upper part of the anterior neck. It is especially susceptible to injury during carotid endarterectomy.   

Features of hypoglossal nerve injury include tongue atrophy and fasciculations and ipsilateral paralysis of one-half of the tongue. Moreover, when the patient is asked to stick out their tongue, the tongue will deviate towards the side of nerve injury.  



Option Analysis

✅ Right carotid artery endarterectomy :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ History of stroke involving the right medullary branch of the vertebral artery :
Incorrect: A stroke involving the medullary branch of the vertebral artery will result in medial medullary syndrome. The condition is associated with hypoglossal nerve palsy, contralateral weakness of the body, and contralateral sensory loss. In contrast, this patient has isolated hypoglossal nerve palsy, which would more likely arise as a complication of carotid surgery.
❌ Lymph node biopsy from the posterior cervical lymph nodes:
Incorrect: The spinal accessory nerve can be injured during a lymph node biopsy in the posterior cervical region. Spinal accessory nerve injury can present with shoulder pain, limited abduction of the shoulder beyond 90 degrees, and shoulder drop. However, it would not present with dysarthria, dysphagia, or tongue deviation.
❌ Thyroidectomy with superior and inferior thyroid arteries dissection :
Incorrect: The superior laryngeal nerve can be injured during dissection of the superior thyroid artery, and the recurrent laryngeal nerve can be damaged during dissection of the inferior thyroid artery. However, this patient’s symptoms are more suggestive of hypoglossal nerve injury.
❌ Mitral stenosis associated with left atrial dilation :
Incorrect: Left atrial dilation can cause compression of the left recurrent laryngeal nerve and associated hoarseness of the voice. In contrast, this patient’s symptoms suggest hypoglossal nerve injury.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man comes to the physician to evaluate dysphagia and hoarseness that have been ongoing for the past three days. He has dysphagia with both solids and liquids. He has a history of poorly controlled hypertension. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 160/85 mmHg, and pulse is 92/min. Physical examination reveals decreased sensation over the posterior aspect of the tongue. The uvula deviates towards the right side. The appearance of the uvula suggests loss of function of which of the following nerves?
questions.solution:
The vagus nerve carries parasympathetic motor fibers to the somatic organs. It also provides motor supply to the muscles of the larynx, pharynx and soft palate.   

The main motor nucleus of the vagus nerve is situated within the reticular formation of the medulla oblongata. It receives inputs from the corticonuclear fibers and sends motor impulses via the direct pharyngeal branches of the vagus nerve to the constrictor muscles of the pharynx and soft palate (except for the tensor palatini muscles) and intrinsic muscles of the larynx.    

The uvula is a centrally located conic projection from the soft palate. If the pharyngeal branch of the vagus nerve is injured, the uvula will deviate away from the side of the lesion and towards the contralateral (unaffected) side. This phenomenon occurs due to a combination of intact palatal muscle pull on the contralateral side and palatal droop on the ipsilateral side.  

Additional symptoms seen in high vagal injuries include dysphagia from palatal weakness and paralysis of the constrictor muscles, in addition to hoarseness from impaired sensation from the superior laryngeal nerve (another branch of the vagus nerve).  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Right vagus nerve:
Incorrect: The uvula deviates towards the contralateral side from the causative lesion. As a result, rightwards deviation of the uvula is suggestive of a left vagus nerve injury.
✅ Left vagus nerve:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Left glossopharyngeal nerve :
Incorrect: Uvular deviation is due to vagal nerve injury and subsequent loss of palatal muscle function. Glossopharyngeal nerve injury does not cause uvular deviation.   
❌ Right glossopharyngeal nerve :
Incorrect: Uvular deviation is due to vagal nerve injury and subsequent loss of palatal muscle function. Glossopharyngeal nerve injury does not cause uvular deviation. 
❌ Left hypoglossal nerve :
Incorrect: The hypoglossal nerve is responsible for the movement of the tongue. Loss of the left hypoglossal nerve function will result in ipsilateral tongue deviation. In contrast, uvular deviation is due to vagus nerve injury.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presents to the physician to evaluate right shoulder weakness, which has been ongoing for three months. The symptom has limited her daily activities, such as brushing her hair. Vital signs are within normal limits. The patient has weakness abducting the right shoulder above 90 degrees on physical examination. In addition, there is atrophy of the right trapezius muscle. The findings are concerning for a nerve injury. Through which of the following mechanisms did this nerve injury likely occur?

choices.text: Lymph node biopsy in the posterior cervical triangle.
Thyroidectomy with superior thyroid artery dissection
Thyroidectomy with inferior thyroid artery dissection

questions.solution:
The spinal accessory nerve, or cranial nerve XI, consists of a spinal portion originating from the ventral horns of the upper four cervical segments of the spinal cord which is then joined by accessory components that arise from the nucleus accumbens of the medulla oblongata.  

These two components form the eleventh cranial nerve, and together, they exit the skull through the jugular foramen. The spinal accessory nerve then courses below the posterior belly of the digastric and upper end of the sternocleidomastoid muscle (SCM). It emerges from the posterior border of the SCM and crosses the posterior triangle before entering the trapezius. Recall, the posterior triangle of the neck is bounded inferiorly by the middle one-third of the clavicle, anteriorly by the posterior border of the sternocleidomastoid, and posteriorly by the anterior border of the trapezius.  

Cranial nerve XI is particularly susceptible to injury as it courses through the posterior triangle of the neck. Injury is most commonly caused by iatrogenic etiologies (e.g., lymph node biopsy, neck dissection) but can also be caused by trauma or tumors.  

Injury to the spinal accessory nerve can lead to paralysis of both the trapezius and sternocleidomastoid muscles. Clinical symptoms include shoulder pain, limited abduction of the shoulder beyond 90 degrees, and shoulder drop. These symptoms may impact an individual’s ability to complete daily tasks, such as combing one’s hair.  



Option Analysis

✅ Lymph node biopsy in the posterior cervical triangle. :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Thyroidectomy with superior thyroid artery dissection :
Incorrect: The external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve can be injured during thyroidectomies due to its proximity with the superior thyroid artery. Patients with this nerve injury may notice changes in voice quality but would not typically experience difficulty abducting the shoulder.   
❌ Thyroidectomy with inferior thyroid artery dissection :
Incorrect: The recurrent laryngeal nerve is susceptible to injury during dissection of the inferior thyroid artery. Patients with recurrent laryngeal nerve injury may experience hoarseness of the voice but not difficulty abducting the shoulder. 
❌ Left atrial enlargement:
Incorrect: Left atrial enlargement can compress the recurrent laryngeal nerve, not the spinal accessory nerve. 
❌ Medial medullary syndrome :
Incorrect: Medial medullary syndrome is caused by occlusion of the medullary branch of the vertebral artery. It results in a lower motor neuron hypoglossal nerve injury in addition to contralateral hemiparesis and contralateral loss of proprioception and tactile discrimination.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy presents to the emergency department for evaluation of trauma to his right thumb. The patient was playing with his brother when he accidentally slammed the door on the patient’s thumb. Physical exam shows the patient has an avulsion injury of the right thumbnail. In order to repair the injury without significant pain, the emergency physician performs a digital block via injection of xylocaine at the base of the right thumb. Which of the following types of nerve fibers anesthetized during this procedure are most susceptible to blockade by the aforementioned medication?
questions.solution:
This patient undergoes a peripheral nerve block with xylocaine for repair of a nail avulsion injury to the right thumb. When considering the type of nerve fibers best anesthetized by local anesthetics, the size factor predominates over myelination such that small myelinated fibers are most sensitive to these medications.      

Local anesthetics inlude medications such as procaine, tetracaine, benzocaine, chloroprocaine, lidocaine, mepivacaine, bupivacaine, and ropivacaine and all carry a similar mechanism of action. These medications all work by binding to specific receptors on the inner portion of the sodium channel, preventing the flow of sodium ions, and subsequently blocking the initiation and propagation of action potentials. Local anesthetics are most effective at blocking fast firing nerves--e.g. smaller fibers. Myelinated fibers are blocked more easily than unmyelinated fibers. In the setting of two fibers with equal degrees of myelination, the smaller fiber will be more sensitive to local anesthesia.      

In accordance with this pattern, the degree of sensation loss after administration of local anesthetics includes pain first, followed by temperature, touch, and finally pressure. In addition, pain firing fibers tend to be located more superficially in tissues, such that fibers located in the periphery of a thick nerve bundle are blocked faster than those in the core because they are exposed to higher concentrations of anesthetic.  

Option Analysis

✅  Diameter   Degree of Myelination  2 µm  ++++ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌  Diameter  Degree of Myelination  15 µm ++++ :
Incorrect: These measurements are indicative of Type A alpha nerve fibers, which conduct proprioception and motor movements. This type of neuronal fiber has an overall low sensitivity to local anesthetic blockade.
❌  Diameter   Degree of Myelination  8 µm  ++++ :
Incorrect:  These measurements are indicative of Type A beta nerve fibers, which conduct the sensation of touch and pressure. This type of neuronal fiber has an overall moderate sensitivity to local anesthetic blockade.
❌  Diameter   Degree of Myelination  6 µm +++:
Incorrect: These measurements are indicative of Type A gamma nerve fibers, which innervate muscle spindles. This type of neuronal fiber has an overall moderate sensitivity to local anesthetic blockade.
❌  Diameter   Degree of Myelination  .5 µm-:
Incorrect: These measurements are indicative of Type C dorsal root ganglion fibers, which conduct pain. This type of pain fiber is small and unmyelinated, and has a high sensitivity to blockade via administration of local anesthetics. However, given the anatomic location of the aforementioned procedure, these fibers would not be blocked.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents for evaluation of a boil on his upper back. The patient initially had a small comeodone that he scratched, and it subsequently progressed to become larger and more painful over the past week. The patient has a history of multiple sclerosis and takes baclofen daily for treatment of muscle spasms. The patient has an allergy to tetracaine, and broke out in hives when having a laceration repaired several years ago. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates a 2 cm x 2 cm fluctuant abscess over the thoracic spine. The patient is subsequently injected with bupivacaine subcutaneously, directly over the area of highest fluctuance in preparation for incision and drainage. A stab incision is made over the anesthetized area; however, the patient reports significant pain despite administration of bupivacaine. Which of the following best describes the etiology of the phenomenon described above?
questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of an upper back abscess and has a local amide anesthetic injected prior to incision and drainage. Unfortunately, this provider did not adequately assess for post-injection analgesia – which was poorly controlled in this patient, likely due to injection into acidic tissue.    

Local anesthetics include medications such as procaine, tetracaine, benzocaine, chloroprocaine, lidocaine, mepivacaine, bupivacaine, and ropivacaine and all carry a similar mechanism of action. These medications all work by binding to specific receptors on the inner portion of the sodium channel, physically preventing the flow of sodium ions, and subsequently blocking the initiation and propagation of action potentials.   

These medications are inherently weak organic bases that are composed of charged and uncharged forms when in solution–only the uncharged forms are able to exert effects on sodium channels. In acidic solutions (such as in infected tissue), lower pH reduces the proportion of anesthetic in the uncharged form according to Henderson-Hasselbalch equation, resulting in decreased ability for the anesthetic to penetrate the neuronal membrane. Ultimately, this results in more anesthetic required to anesthetize this type of tissue. 

Option Analysis

✅ Increased acidity of injected tissue :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Localized allergic reaction :
Incorrect: While this patient has an allergy to ester anesthetics, he is provided with an amide anesthetic, bupivacaine. This patient's clinical presentation is not consistent with an allergy reaction.  
❌ Medication interaction :
Incorrect: Baclofen does not interact with administration of local anesthetics.   
❌ Poor injection technique :
Incorrect: The provider described in this vignette used adequate technique for local anesthesia--the issue was likely injecting an insufficient amount of anesthetic.   
❌ Degradation of injected medication :
Incorrect: Local anesthetics are not degraded when injected into acidic tissue--they can degrade over time if left out, especially in sunlight environments.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of a finger laceration. The patient was cutting tomatoes in the kitchen when the knife slipped and he sustained a laceration to his left middle finger.  The patient is subsequently injected with a medication on the palmar aspect of his left hand just proximal to the left middle finger. After several minutes the patient reports absence of pain, but can still sense pressure. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of the medication utilized in this procedure?

choices.text: Non-specific blockade of voltage gated Na+ channels
Inhibition of release of acetylcholine from presynaptic motor neurons

questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of a finger laceration and subsequently has a digital block performed with administration of a local anesthetic. The mechanism of action of these medications involves non-specific blockade of voltage gated Na+ channels to block neuronal transmission of pain signals.  

Local anesthetics include medications such as procaine, tetracaine, benzocaine, chloroprocaine, lidocaine, mepivacaine, bupivacaine, and ropivacaine and all carry a similar mechanism of action. These medications work by binding to specific receptors on the inner portion of the sodium channel, physically preventing the flow of sodium ions, and subsequently blocking the initiation and propagation of action potentials. These medications are most effective in rapidly firing, small diameter, highly myelinated neurons, which comprise the majority of pain associated fibers. Thus local anesthetics are exceptionally effective agents for nerve blocks, minor skin procedures, or prior to placement of indwelling catheters.  

Option Analysis

✅ Non-specific blockade of voltage gated Na+ channels:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ NMDA receptor antagonism:
Incorrect: NMDA receptor antagonism describes the mechanism of action of ketamine, a dissociative analgesic. This medication is commonly used for procedural sedation, not local anesthesia.   
❌ Acetylcholine receptor agonist :
Incorrect: Depolarizing nerve agents such as succinylcholine function by selectively binding acetylcholine, and inducing prolonged depolarization, preventing muscle contraction. These medications are frequently utilized as paralytic agents during rapid sequence intubation, not for local analgesia.   
❌ Acetylcholine receptor antagonism:
Incorrect: Non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking medications such as rocuronium work by competitively binding the acetylcholine receptor, preventing muscle contraction. Like depolarizing neuromuscular blockers, these medications are not used for local analgesia.   
❌ Inhibition of release of acetylcholine from presynaptic motor neurons:
Incorrect: This stem describes the mechanism of action of botulinum toxin, the agent found in the medication botox, used to achieve long-term muscle paralysis. This medication is not used for local analgesia.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of a laceration to the right forearm. The patient was jumping over a fence when he slipped and sustained a 3 cm laceration to his right volar forearm. Prior to repair of the laceration, a local anesthetic agent is injected around the edges of the wound. Next, the physician performs a test of sensation to determine readiness for repair. Which of the following best lists the order in which sensations are lost after administration of the aforementioned medication?
questions.solution:
This patient is provided with a peripheral nerve block with a local anesthetic for repair of a forearm laceration. Prior to repair of lacerations it is commonplace to check for adequate regional analgesia--usually by gently tapping the wound edges with a pin, or the sharp end of scissors. The order of sensation loss following administration of a local anesthetic is Pain>Temperature>Touch>Pressure.     

Local anesthetics include medications such as procaine, tetracaine, benzocaine, chloroprocaine, lidocaine, mepivacaine, bupivacaine, and ropivacaine and all carry a similar mechanism of action. These medications all work by binding to specific receptors on the inner portion of the sodium channel, physically preventing the flow of sodium ions, and subsequently blocking the initiation and propagation of action potentials. Local anesthetics are most effective at blocking fast firing nerves--e.g. smaller fibers and myelinated fibers are blocked more easily than unmyelinated fibers. In the setting of two fibers with equal degrees of myelination, the smaller fiber will be more sensitive to local anesthesia.    

In accordance with this pattern, the degree of sensation loss after administration of local anesthetics includes pain first, followed by temperature, touch, and finally pressure. In addition, pain firing fibers tend to be located more superficially in tissues, such that fibers located in the periphery of a thick nerve bundle are blocked faster than those in the core because they are exposed to higher concentrations of anesthetic.   

Option Analysis

✅ Pain>Temperature>Touch>Pressure :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Temperature>Touch>Pressure>Pain:
Incorrect: Pain is the first sensation to be lost after administration of local anesthetics, not the last.   
❌ Pressure>Touch>Pain>Temperature:
Incorrect: Pressure and touch are lost after pain and temperature, not before.   
❌ Pain>Pressure>Touch>Temperature:
Incorrect: Pain is the first sensation to be lost after administration of local anesthetics; however, pressure and touch are the last to be lost, not temperature.   
❌ Temperature> Pain >Touch>Pressure:
Incorrect: Pain is lost before temperature, not temperature before pain.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man comes to the office to evaluate right-sided facial heaviness for the past 10 hours. He also reports decreased tear production on the right side and the inability to tolerate loud sounds that started simultaneously. Medical history is remarkable for a right-sided parotid gland adenoma which was surgically resected one month ago. The patient has no hearing loss, ringing sensation in the ears, or difficulty walking. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination findings are shown in the image below.

 


Examination of the right auditory canal and auricle is noncontributory. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the findings seen in this patient?

choices.text: Lower motor neuron lesion of the involved cranial nerve
Upper motor neuron lesion of the involved cranial nerve

questions.solution:
With paralysis of the upper and lower right side of the face, together with loss of tear production and hyperacusis, this patient most likely has Bell palsy, a mononeuropathy affecting the lower motor neuron of the facial nerve (CN VII). The etiology is often idiopathic, with the possible cause being viral-associated ischemic demyelination (e.g., herpes simplex, Epstein-Barr) or sometimes as a complication of Lyme disease or sarcoidosis.

The motor pathway for the facial nerve starts from the motor cortex, where its upper motor neuron (UMN) travels downwards through the internal capsule to reach the facial motor nucleus in the lateral pons. This nucleus has a dorsal and ventral part. The former innervates muscles of the upper face and lacrimation, while the latter innervates muscles of the lower face and salivation. The dorsal region receives innervation from the UMN of both hemispheres. The ventral region receives innervation only from the UMN of the opposite hemisphere. That is why unilateral UMN lesions (e.g. stroke) only affect the lower part of the face on the contralateral side.

The UMN fibers cross over before they synapse with LMN, which then travel ipsilaterally, supplying the same side of the face. Therefore, an LMN lesion affects the upper and lower side of the face ipsilaterally.





Option Analysis

✅ Lower motor neuron lesion of the involved cranial nerve:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Upper motor neuron lesion of the involved cranial nerve:
Incorrect: Unilateral UMN lesions (e.g. stroke) only affect the lower part of the face on the contralateral side. The upper facial muscles receive dual innervation from the ipsilateral and contralateral sides, which means upper facial muscles are spared when there is an upper motor neuron lesion of the facial nerve. This patient has paralysis on the right side of the upper and lower facial muscles, making a UMN lesion unlikely.
❌ Reactivation of a dormant virus:
Incorrect: The major complication of reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus is the Ramsay Hunt syndrome, which typically includes the triad of ipsilateral facial paralysis, ear pain, and vesicles in the auditory canal and auricle. This patient does not have otalgia, and physical examination of the auricle and auditory canal is unremarkable.
❌ Recent surgery:
Incorrect: The motor component of the facial nerve enters the parotid gland before it divides into the terminal branches to innervate the facial muscles. Injury to this area can lead to ipsilateral paralysis of the facial muscles. However, it would not explain the sudden onset of symptoms one month after the procedure and the hyperacusis in this patient.
❌ Tumor at the cerebellopontine angle:
Incorrect: Even though a tumor at the cerebellopontine angle (e.g. schwannoma) can sometimes involve the facial nerve, it is usually preceded by the symptoms of CN VIII impingement (i.e., tinnitus, ataxia, vertigo, or sensorineural hearing loss), none of which are seen in this patient.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of facial weakness. Earlier that morning, he had trouble drinking water, as it was drooling from the side of his mouth. When he looked in the mirror, he noticed the right side of his face was drooping, and he could not move his mouth or eyebrow on that side. He has no past medical history. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows an asymmetric smile, loss of the right nasolabial fold, and drooping of the right eyelid. The rest of the neurologic examination is noncontributory. Extensive workup, including Lyme serology and MRI of the brain, is unremarkable. A provisional diagnosis of cranial nerve paralysis secondary to a viral infection is made. In addition to facial weakness, which of the following findings is this patient most likely to demonstrate?

choices.text: Ipsilateral loss of facial touch sensation
Loss of taste of the anterior third of the tongue
Inability to sweat on the right of the face
Ipsilateral loss of the pupillary light reflex

questions.solution:
This patient with paralysis of the upper (drooping of the eyelid, inability to move eyebrow) and lower (loss of nasolabial fold, drooping of the lips, asymmetric smile) right side of the face most likely has Bell palsy, a mononeuropathy affecting the facial nerve (CN VII).

The facial nerve is a mixed nerve, with the following functions:

  • Motor: Facial muscles involved in facial expressions, eye closure, and the stapedius (which contracts to dampen loud sounds) 
  • Somatic sensory: Afferents from the area of the pinna and external auditory canal 
  • Special sensory: Afferents for taste from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue 
  • Parasympathetic innervation of the submandibular, sublingual and lacrimal glands
